>Sorry I've been a bit behind on following this thread so this answer 
>may be obsolete by now, but it is not so much a question of what is 
>necessary as much as just being consistent with past experiments 
>(after all, that's what makes it a benchmark).   Certainly there are 
>cases once in a while where a 10,000 timestep network can fail at 
>100,000 timesteps.  Whether that matters, or whether all our lives 
>would have been easier if they'd originally just decided to call it 
>a day at 10,000 is no longer really possible to debate unless you 
>want to stop comparing with predecessors.  Personally, I would have 
>preferred to stop at 10,000.  Then again, Gruau may have had good 
>reason for the 100,000 test.
>

 From what I've seen in my experiments, if a network achieves 100,000 
steps then it will balance a pole indefinitely in the simulator. Of 
course if the poles are moving in a none chaotic manner then you can 
assume they will balance forever. If however they are moving chaotically 
then you cannot assume that some future state won't destabilise the 
system - good solutions on the anti-wiggle test though seem to keep the 
poles almost perfectly upright, which doesn't mean the system is 
non-chaotic, but I would rate the chances of  a dramatic destabilisation 
of such an apparently stable system to be low.

Colin
